awd_titl_txt: Dimensions USBIOTA- Sao Paulo: Collaborative Proposal: Traits as predictors of adaptive diversification along the Brazilian Dry Diagonal
awd_abstract_narration:
The Brazilian Dry Diagonal (BDD) is a broad region of diverse and unique habitats sandwiched in between the wetter Amazon basin to the west and the moist tropical and subtropical Atlantic Forest to the east. Although the BDD can appear superficially to be wasteland with little variety, in fact it harbors many unique species, comprise the most endangered set of habitats in Brazil, and is being rapidly being lost to agriculture and other human encroachment. This research will be the first to synthesize information from species' traits, communities, and genetics to understand how the unique traits and communities of organisms living in the BDD evolved. Using a diverse set of approaches to study in detail a variety of animals, plants and fungi that today inhabit this broad swath of dry habitats in central Brazil, the researchers will evaluate: 1) what sorts of traits - such as body size, shape or specific behaviors - allow a group of organisms to succeed in a novel environment? 2) how the novel environment determines the set of organisms - the community - that we see today? 3) how organisms adapt genetically and morphologically to that novel environment? and 4) how novel traits, communities, and genetic changes interact to produce the variety of organisms that are seen in different environments today? Answers to these questions will improve scientists' ability to predict the impacts of a changing world on biodiversity. The project will foster new international research collaborations by engaging a large team of experts from the United States and Brazil and will also provide interdisciplinary research training opportunities for undergraduate students, graduate students and post-doctoral researchers.   

To accomplish the four aims listed above, the project will first use a machine learning approach applied to hundreds of traits and lineages in the BDD to determine which traits predict evolutionary success - the tendency for xeric-adapted species to undergo evolutionary diversification. The project will then employ community phylogenetics approaches to understand how functional trait variation is distributed in the BDD, and will determine the evolutionary patterns and over- or under-dispersion of trait values observed in particular communities inhabiting the BDD today, as well as how traits are filtered across habitat gradients. Finally, the project uses a variety of genomic technologies, including whole genome sequencing and transcriptomics, to understand how organisms adapt to the more xeric habitats of the BDD as compared to close relatives living in adjacent mesic biomes. By linking evolutionary patterns in traits, communities and genes, the project will synthesize the functional, phylogenetic and genetic dimensions of biodiversity of the BDD and present a comprehensive portrait of its origins and evolution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project is to examine how species form between unique environments in Brazil and address associated adaptations that permit organisms to evolve in these environments. Brazil is the most biodiverse country on Earth and it is still largely unknown how most species form in the sharply environmentally contrasting and threatened biomes of this country. We explore the origins of lizard species and their adaptations to the large, poorly studied, yet highly threatened biomes comprising the Brazilian “Dry Diagonal” (BDD) by examining their traits, genomes, and evolutionary trees. Lizards are useful for examining these questions because they are diverse and because closely related species occur in many of these habitats throughout Brazil. We used a combination of genomic and trait data collected from lizards in the field and developed custom machine learning code to demonstrate that most species found in the BDD originated from the forested wet tropics (Amazonia, the Atlantic Rainforest). This was 80% more common than the reverse, where species in the forested wet tropics originated from the BDD. The following traits were most associated with adaptations to the dryer habitats in the BDD: body temperature, microhabitat, female snout–vent length and diet. In addition, we found that divergences between the forested wetter biomes and the BDD occurred over long  time periods, from the early Miocene (23 million years ago) to the latest Pleistocene (23,000 years ago) and that gene exchange is still common among very divergent species each adapted to these unique environments. So far two contrasting situations have been found: 1) anciently diverged species between forested and open biomes show that only a few areas of the genome permits genes exchange between species and 2) young species showing only a few areas of the genome where genes are not exchanged. Therefore, this demonstrates that speciation can occur over a wide spectrum of gene exchanges across the genome and over a long time frame separated between open dry and wet forested biomes. This suggests that speciation can occur in very unique ways even among physiologically similar and related organisms like lizards. The project provides a set of unique methods to address how species remain distinct even though they still exchange genes, showing that some gene copies associated with unique environments are never or rarely exchanged between species. The project resulted in the production of 127 high quality lizard genomes and many needed specimens collected over four expeditions to the BDD. These expeditions also resulted in the discovery of several new species of frogs and lizards. This also resulted in the training of one postdoc in field, lab, and analytical genomic methods, one museum specialist, and many graduate and undergraduate students from the US and Brazil involved in expeditions and a genomic workshop held at the American Museum of Natural History.
